text:
Been watching your videos since you made the bmx video in Belgium. Weekly I check your channel for new videos. I don't know if it's because of we are around the same age or it's because we have the same intrests, but your videos always seem to 'inspire' me (wathever the content is) BMX , drifting,  love for JDM, the joy of working at cars with friends. To be honest, this is the first time I react to one of your videos, just because I know every single video you make will please me.. The thing I love most is that you spend money the way a 'carguy' would spend money! You're not a yter that spends his money on 'his dreamcar' but doesn't know the difference between a 12gallo and a 24gallo. Watching your videos(lifestyle) makes me jealous, wich is a good way to inspire people to do something.
Keep that up! 
Regards a long time fan!

text:
As far as likes, I will usually hit like when I want to easily save something to show people later.

You did bring up a good point I forget often. When I actually like a channel I'll subscribe but never really hit the like button on their videos. I actually like the videos I'm watching and just forget that the button can help them reach new people.




I think its two completely different things to say "LETS SEE IF WE CAN GET 100K LIKES" versus reminding people like me saying "If you liked this video please hit like so new people can find this"


One more thing of note. I watch mostly car / industry related videos. I get recommended your videos a lot.
Even though I wasn't subscribed to you, your videos come up often enough I can somewhat keep up and was a member of your audience. 

Reminding your audience in a causal way to help out by hitting two buttons that cost nothing and take no effort to press pales in comparison to filming and editing these videos.



(Also Cleetus McFarland's 100k likes for a mullet was dope.)

text:
So don't commit here much, but I hit the like button if I like the video. Looks like you are wondering how the channel is doing and where to go from here, but you probably already know what needs to be done. From what I have notice ,is that on car channels if you get about 20-25% as many views as you have subscribers you are in good shape. When you are below that range you have something going on, either you have a lot of dead subs or you are just not connecting with your views well ( irrelevant content). If I had to guess, I would say it is a mix of both for you. A lot of your OG subscribers are from your BMX days ( was close to a million back then) and you have not really made much BMX content lately. On the other side to make good car related content, you need the team of people to tie up the loose ends. Sounds like you understand this when you said it's hard to do good videos when you have to work on the cars non stop instead of having Alberto fix it. 
So to me it sounds like your going to have to go back to Florida soon where you have everything setup to do car, drift and BMX videos. I understand that going back has emotional things tied to it, but it might be time to deal with that. You might have to sell that house or something if it is a trigger. You had a good set up down there, BMX park in the backyard , drift and dragstrip close by, and other car YouTubers close by that are killing it ( Cleetus). Just thinking out loud man, you have been doing this for a while and have had a lot of success and know what to do. I think when you get to a place where you are truly comfortable the likes will come back. Wishing you the best man sorry this was such a long Post.

text: Somehow the projects "back home in Florida" seem more interesting.  Maybe part of it is the interaction with the rest of the crew.  Not that Tommy isn't much fun or interesting just not what I started following the channel for as far as content.  I certainly understand you can't buy a new car every 2 months to sit on the sidelines and collect dust when completed (if there is such a thing as a completed project car). Otherwise you'd need a real warehouse or build giveaway cars most of the time or maybe sell a car from time to time to kept the fleet size under control.  I certainly prefer this content over the Formula Drift content as several others have mentioned but it is a part of your life and since we are "family" (according to you) I guess it's a part of our life.  Anyway just my $.02 worth and yes you got more relevant from yet another comment.  Hey new project car idea, Mazda RX-7 FD.  Alberto might be on board with that sort of project car as well even though it isn't a NIssan or an EVO.  Before you say everyone else has built an FD, which is true for the most part, keep in mind the viewing "families" seem to eat it up best I can tell.  I know I do.  It's a bucket list car for me as my Dad had a 1st gen and an FC and I enjoy practically all projects involving FDs.  Might even enjoy seeing one converted to V8.  Enough already I'm sure you're tired of reading this as well.

text:
Fix the leaks to stop the alternators dying.
If the alternator gets coated in oil the dust from the carbon brushes in the alternator will form an abrasive paste, this will then coat the alternator internernals and the carbon brushes will degrade quickly.

text: I'm sure this won't get read but it's worth a shot. You might need a higher output alternator than your current OEM alternator. You aren't driving a stock Evolution 5. I assume your car has upgraded parts that run off your electrical system, like the fuel pump and etc. Sometimes OEM alternators are ill-equipped to handle the extra load from those upgrades. Maybe you should call an alternator company like Iraggi or Mechman and explain your situation so they can try to help fix the problems you are having. I was having the same issue as you but caused by a different reason. My first vehicle I ever owned had a upgraded sound system. The car was completely stock minus the head unit, 600 watt amplifier, two 12" subwoofers, four door speakers and an Optima battery. Even with the upgraded battery, the OEM alternator could not keep up and the voltage would drop causing the lights to dim. You might also want to make sure the electrical system is properly grounded. In the car audio world, there is an upgrade called the big three upgrade. It consists of upgrading three wires to a larger gauge wire. The three include the battery ground to chassis wire, the chassis to engine block wire, and the alternator plus to battery plus wire. Also, if the car has a voltage regulator, it might be going bad. Hopefully this helps.

text:
I use the Like button primarily to save videos. 

If what you say is actually the case than I will like and comment for sure, why not it's only 3 seconds out of my day. 

In terms of content. I really enjoy these more solo mechanical videos. To me it reminds me that you're not just a pretty boy YouTube drifter that relies on others to build but one that has somewhat of a clue and the capabilities to do it alone.

Imagine all the new viewers rocking up and only experiencing "Year of the Flex" all they'd be seeing is you goofing around and having fun. Which is all well and good but at that point the image is just a "guy with money spending money" which is fun for a bit but ends up being the same regurgitated content. 

Content like this shows that you have a multifaceted personality and aren't just another "kid" with money.

I am missing Alberto though. <3

#nohomo?maybealittle

text:
I rarely like videos. In my last 7 years or so on YouTube, I have only liked about 350 videos. I will, however, like a video if I really love it or it‚Äôs extremely funny. Like the FD videos for example. 
Or Cleetus running a 7 or something. I have hung around this channel since  2013ish, and the last month or so has been one of the first times that I haven‚Äôt been watching the daily videos. I just kind of liked the Florida vlogs better. 
But, if you enjoy being in CT, and it helps your mental health, don‚Äôt listen to us. Stay there if you feel comfy there. 
I will say that the best cure for depression is working out: bodybuilding, heavyweight, etc. I had a suicidal depression 3 years ago and the thing that got me back on track was bodybuilding and reading the daily political news. Thanks for reading my novel. üá∫üá∏

author: J Marshall

text:
I like your video's as soon as I agree with you, which is usually pretty often.
For your power surge m8; check your grounds first, not just the engine bay ones. That light surge is where the lights are supposed to be, you're actually missing power 3/4 strokes it seems from the clip. I once had celica alltrac that had a bad ground near the stereo that caused this same issue.

Don't make power over complicated. Check grounds and then check any positives that are shorted to ground (meaning a tear in the wire touching the chassis). Also, the alternator probably got week from something shorted to ground and making it overwork itself, the grease would have little affect as it isn't conductive enough and would only affect its thermals.


I would put money on that you have a short somewhere, doubt it's in the engine bay since I'm sure you've checked that dozens of times. Check near window motors, stereo, door locks, ecu, gauge cluster, aftermarket gauges, anywhere that could possibly be a short. I would check anything that I've touched or installed first, sad but, usually things like this are unintentionally self induced.

After you fix the issue, you may need to bring your idle back down.

text: Liking and Subscribing are one of the most intuitive aspects of being on YouTube. Just about everyone knows whether they like a video or dislike, and even if they want to subscribe. Mentioning to like and subscribe in every video personally turns me away from doing so. If you're making genuine content, people will come to notice and will like the video. Then there will be no need to mention it as long as youre okay with the outcome of the video. If your video is like-worth and sub-worthy to you, others will see that too. But, if you need the approval from others to know if they liked the video or not.  I don't think that's the way of pushing the like and sub button. People will do it if they feel and if they want to.

text:
I usually only like videos when I feel like I want to show the video to a friend.  My like's videos playlist is pretty sparse.  That being said, sometimes I will like videos if there is an incentive to like the video to make a change to the channel.  Liking every video I actually enjoy feels like a chore these days, especially when I watch so much youtube content..  Not a great excuse, but yeah.


I only comment on a video when the feedback the creator asks for seems meaningful.  For example "comment on this video if you think this thing is dumb" seems like an attention grab.  "comment on this video to provide me feedback on why you do or don't like videos" seems a lot more meaningful, you know?  I may just be lazy, but it is what it is.

text:
In my case i like everyone of your videos, i only follow a few channels but i only like every video on your channel, with other youtubers it depends on the content. For example, even though you don't upload only one tipe of video ( i mean, you make videos of different contents, like riding, drifting, building a car, etc) you mantain a main topic, and mix it with other activities that i also like. The other channels i follow, they don't do that, one video is about a topic and the next one is about something completely different, so that video has to be really good, or have something that catches my attention to get the like.
Furthermore, i have learnt a lot with your videos, from working on a car, to the language, and that is something that i really appreciate.
I think you should make more videos like this one, working on your cars, teaching how to do it, including mistakes, as you did in the past ( you keep doing it, but in the past you used to make way more videos working in your cars and teaching us [yes, i know that you now have waaay more things going on, but this videos are awesome too]). I like when you show us the mistakes you make, because we learn from that and you keep it real, that makes this interesting.
Sorry if i have grammar mistakes, not a native english speaker. Love your channel!
Keep up the good work
Regards from Argentina ü§òüèº

text: Steven Forbes I feel like this creates the wrong idea. He needs accurate feedback on content, that‚Äôs why he‚Äôs trying to see what‚Äôs causing the channel to Plato. If everyone was forced to give there honest opinion, yes I liked or no I didn‚Äôt like, then it would be easier to narrow down the small details about videos that people don‚Äôt like. Obviously we all like when he does something big. But if you press like on everything then you‚Äôll cancel out someone else who maybe disliked it for various reasons. It‚Äôs one thing if every single upload gassed you up and but you said you‚Äôre doing it out of respect, which maybe isn‚Äôt the best or most helpful reason to press the button. Judge the content of the video, not the creator as a whole. For example, Tommy f yeah is amazing and I respect what he has done, but when that rav 4 pops up on screen I dislike the video. Not to say I don‚Äôt watch it, but I just don‚Äôt care about it. I skip around and probably don‚Äôt finish. I‚Äôm pretty sure youtubers can see these metrics. So while I‚Äôm showing my support and trying to watch what he produced the content doesn‚Äôt peak my interest. I‚Äôm also trying to send a message to cut it out with lame left field content, and focus on other things.

text: I feel like the like button is just another thing I have to worry about as a content consumer and a previous creator. It's annoying, unhelpful, and ultimately not a very useful metric in my opinion. When it boils down to your content, the people who like YOU as a person, your personality, ect will stay and help the channel grow because they stick around. But, if I'm really being honest I'm just lazy and have grown so accustomed to watching the channels I subscribe to that I don't bother thinking about likes on a video, or liking the video because I feel like my subscription is enough. Obviously new people who watch your videos, you want them to hit the like button, but if I'm being honest I think the most important metric is the view count of each video with the mindset that you have millions of subscribers already. However what I think you should really be looking at is how many subscribers CONSISTENTLY watch your videos, and today I don't know what tools YouTube gives creators in terms of seeing that, but if your subscriber viewership is poor that signal to me that something is not up to par with my content or videos ect... So, I would look into that and give that some serious thought and consideration as to why X amount of viewers who are subscribed actually watch. I mean you have channels that have over 10 million subscribers, and they can get millions of views, but how many of those say 2 millions views are from actual subscribers? Personally I don't know, but for a lot of very popular channels it seems like their viewership is more of an artificial and or superficial relationship with that creator. Therefore, I really think that even at a reasonably high rate of subscriptions, say 50%, that 1 million subscribers on a channel with 10 million or so is a retention rate of 10% out of 100. That's. Not. Good. It's not good because it shows that the subscribed viewership isn't actively participating, but more importantly they probably don't care about the creators content. In your case Adam I don't know how to necessarily explain your analytics. Only you can ask your audience what it is that they want to see, and what they don't. But, it is really nice to hear a content creator think about growing their channel in a constructive way. To answer your question if you need to bribe Tommy, no you don't. I don't need something outlandish to like it. I already like it in my head so I feel like hitting the like button is an extra unnecessary step which I already said. This is for Adam, but also for all the other content creators out there. Just keep doing your thing, but forget about the likes, the dislikes, the hate comments, ect... it's all white noise and you've got bigger things to deal with than them. Also I don't comment often on what I really feel because YouTube has never been the kindest to me. However, I care about the progression of this channel and the fact that Adam calls us, "Family" shows just how much he cares about his viewers and not just himself. This took way too long to type out but I will not delete it, and I really hope Adam sees it because he is one of the better content creators in my opinion, (again), but I just want him to see that someone else actually cares too.

text: I personally try to like every video I watch because it helps support the channel. However, if I‚Äôm at home, I‚Äôm watching videos on my Xbox, in which the user interface makes it much more difficult to get to the like button. I also prefer install content and fun stuff content like anybody else. Although, I do enjoy all the content. I think part of the important part about watching YouTube videos, especially when dealing with cars, is education. It‚Äôs very beneficial to me and enjoyable to watch the diagnosis process. I think that goes for anybody, whether they want it or not. I wouldn‚Äôt worry too much about what kind of content is being posted. Life is not always entertaining. As long as you‚Äôre always pushing to do fun stuff obviously. However, boring life stuff can be made entertaining, like messing around with your friends WHILE making an entire video of washing a car, or making fun of Tommy while you replace an oil line. It‚Äôs inspiring to see what a ‚Äúreal world dream life‚Äù is like during the day to day. You can‚Äôt just own a handful of some of the most awesome cars on the planet without working everyday. That‚Äôs why I enjoy it. Goals af. 32yr old male for demographics sake.

author: EvilGenius Gaming

text: 100% guilty of not liking video's across the board. I think it's people being sick of all the dickhead youtubers who beg you to "smash that like button" at the start of a video before they've even provided any like-worthy content to earn that "like" . You kind of get numb to the significance of what a like even represents .You stop associating a "like" with expressing your enjoyment of the content and just dismiss it as some form of currency creators want from you to boost their ratings in the youtube algorithm and give them more clout with advertisers. I wouldn't class you as one of those youtubers but do find that when I really like the content of a video you make , I'm far more likely to engage with a positive comment rather than a like. It's a bit of a catch 22 because you aren't begging for free likes every 2 minutes of the video but at the same time you rarely ask so people forget . You maybe need to find a balance in the middle somewhere .

text: I click like for two reasons.  When i really like a video and it's so good i basically remind myself to like it and when you (the creator) reminds us to like it.  Most times i just forget to like it unless i'm reminded to like it like you're doing here which is why i just clicked the "like" button.  My advice is just to remind people to like right in the middle of something really cool going on like mid engine swap or mid race.  Don't do it at the very beginning and don't do it at the end because people might have already clicked off by then.  Do it right in the middle of the meat of the content and you'll probably get most people to click the button.  Just my two cents.

author: LBC Raiders

text:
If it's a creator like you that I routinely watch, I just habitually like the video. If something happens in the video that I really don't like, I might remove my like or dislike, but that's rare. 

For creators that are new to me, I usually don't like until I find something cool or interesting in the video. If I can watch another video and I like their content, or I was blown away by one video, I will subscribe.


As far as content, I think I personally like your Florida videos better than Connecticut I think because of the content in them. I still love seeing Tommy, Grant, Jimmy, etc. in your CT videos, but it definitely has a different vibe. However, I know you've expressed that you didn't really want to be in FL right now, but you did say you'd probably be in CT more in the summer because of the heat.


I definitely feel like you have a lot of stuff to do, and it has been slightly mundane, but that's not really your fault. Ed from VinWiki actually made it a really good point in his video that he would prefer to watch someone that uploads not as frequently and has more quality content, instead of someone struggling to put content together daily.


In the grand scheme of things, I think the best way to look at your videos is that, the daily videos, like the one today, while not as extravagant as FD, Japan, Germany, etc. are still good videos. Of course they'll get fewer views because they're not as extravagant, but that's expected.


I think if you focus on making one really baller video every week or two weeks, and take one day of the week off, maybe sticking to always post weekends but have a floating day off during the week, you'll feel a little better about your output.


In reality, you've been uploading nearly every single day for the past few years, and it has to be draining, especially when you have to throw FD, your race team, your business and employees, and everything else going on in your life into the mix. 


I think there's a lot of ways you could probably improve your workflow to make it a little bit easier on yourself. Just like you did today, don't be afraid to ask us questions, and don't be afraid to take a day off. My brother is my mentor, and in the Software Engineering world, he said you have to have a good work life balance or you literally will want to commit suicide everyday from the stress. I have gotten in that spot before, and I don't wanna see you eventually dig yourself into a hole from feeling lonely.


I don't know if you'll read this, but I hope it helps. :)

text:
i dont comment nor like videos very often but you asked for the feedback. i have to say i watch all your videos and love the daily content regardless what it is. its what i do almost every day when i get home from work. i think ive liked maybe 5-6 videos ever. 2 were yours. one purely because you were at my local track drifting. the other videos i like are just like WOW moments like once in a life time epic shit. 


I got to say i do enjoy watching you work on your car cause as most car owns that especially modify them know they're a constant upkeep usually. so its nice to see your human and take care of your shit and its fun watching you put parts on your cars that i could only dream about. also learning a bit too from your problems and about different products. one of my favorite parts were those vibrant HD clamps for the intercooler. those things are sick and ive never seen them before. i want to say a lot of people like relatable videos. as do i. if you got a is300 i would like all those videos.


one video id be interested in seeing is your actual day like how long it takes you to set up your camera for certain shops. how long certain shots take. i recall one where it was just a coffee run and you walked back to your car and got in your car and the camera was already in your car recording so it was like you had to walk to your car twice to get that shot. interesting to me. 


another interesting video would be to build a budget drift car maybe. something your basic person can build or maybe even replicate for a small budget. i dont think youve done this before. your give away cars are the closest to that but theyre still pretty dang expensive or rare.


one of my least favorite content is watching you just driving tracks. not drifting. time racing i guess. gets kind of boring after you going around the course 10-15 times throughout the video. unless something bad happens sorry to say just makes good content. might just be boring for me cause im not that into that type of racing. while i could watch you drift the same track 20+ times no problem.


just my 2 cent. dont know if youll even bother reading it. im nobody. hope to see you back at etown soon tho!

text: In the stereo world, when we have voltage issues like yours. We upgrade the "Big 3." or in your case, maybe upgrade the battery and alternator ground cable to a thicker cable.  Check your engine grounding points as well. GL!

text: Yeah shawn d you are correct. Been diagnosing and repairing anything with an engine for 28 yrs. text:
Adam, couple more tips for ya.  You can patch a cut CV boot with a low viscosity BMX tire patch or shoe glue.  Just clean, sand, then clean the surface with brake cleaner before repair.

  Second tip:  for some reason Japanese cars have a lot of parasitic draws on the battery. 
  Use a digital volt ohmmeter on the fused 12v setting. 
  Then go across every fuse in the cars fuse box with the key out of the ignition for 30 minutes before testing.

  With the negative probe grounded at the battery, run the positive probe across the top of the fuses and note which ones still have 12v going to them.
  After you've written notes of the power draw at each appliance, make sure they've adequate grounding.  If that doesn't let them go to sleep completely, then consider adding a toggle switch as an interrupter in each of their ground circuits.

  If there's an abundant amount of appliances that don't go to sleep after the key is removed for 30 minutes, then you can also consider re-routing everything through an aftermarket fused relay distribution block with it's own ground wire kill switch.

  If the battery dies within a few days after sitting un-started, the problem is very likely that you have a positive to positive short circuit.  Probably from an aftermarket electrical addition. That'll definitely ruin an alternator too. 
  The parasitic draw test will find the problem, as long as you've access to each individual circuits fuse.

It seems like a lot at first but after you do it a few times, it'll be a peice of cake.  Don't work too hard, watch some tiger videos for good measure and decompression;)

text:
The Alternator in a SAAB 9-5 is in the same exact spot. You have to pull it from the bottom like that too. I was a smart guy and put a 3" down pipe on mine and it was a bitch taking it out as well because you really have to get your arm in there and you have to look at the connection bolts at just the right angle.

I was listening to a very popular YouTuber and they indicated that comments and likes do not play a big role in the algorithm. I think you guys have to understand that everyday, there are people trying to be a content creator so the platform is getting saturated with new people. You have to market yourself more to get more traffic into your flow. Vista Print some YouTube business cards and give them out to people you meet whenever you go to Lime Rock or anywhere. Monetizing yourself is a never ending game and engaging with the community is critical in a social media platform.

author: Andrew Olsen

text:
amp draw is causing the flickering.
voltage is only showing your alternator is maxed out while still not enough amps for all the electrical load.
take a set of jumper cables and connect them at the front to the head/block then also to chassis.
connect the other ends directly to the ground on the battery .
this will show if you have enough grounds and correct size grounds.
you need a more low rpm amp rated alternator to not work the alternator so hard.
larger amp draw aftermarket fans, lights, and electrical parts are putting to much strain on the oem sized alternator.

text:
Honesty ALERT There are a few channels I automatically hit "Like" and then I watch.  Shmee150 is one. Peterolicious. Larry Chen on Hoonigan Autofocus. Auditography. Hartnett Media, Papadakis Racing.  All of those I smash like, then I watch.  Perhaps it has to do with consistency of content, knowing that things are....perhaps more streamlined with them.  No matter what it's about I know it will be high-grade content, even if it's about a Suzuki Jimny or photographing a 27 year old car, showing how to do safety wire on bolts or showing sick cars with amazing music for 5 mins. I know what I'm getting with them. 

It's like a restaurant you always go to. Perhaps it's not THE best, but it is great value, service and ALWAYS consistent.   

I like your channel. I'm trying to love it, but I am not there.  Your personality has grown on me over the 2 years I've been subscribed.  You're a lot less annoying that TJ üòè (just a friendly dig at a fellow San Diegan). Perhaps sometimes I don't know where your videos are going. Some days they are laced up, like when the Evo content was popping. But somedays...I'm not sure. The vibe feels off or the edits are an odd follow. Like sometimes its putting out content just for contents sake.  So perhaps I don't always smash that like button immediately because of that. 

In the end, you have WAY more subs than me so obviously you've done a lot right. I dont withhold "likes" to be negative, but sometimes I am not all the way bought in. But your channel intrigues me enough to venture back.  üëçüèª
author: B. Chandler
